meanings.definition: To cut off the stem or stems of (a plant) for propagation.
meanings.sent1: I will restem this rose to grow a new one.
meanings.sent2: Gardeners often restem plants to create more of the same species.
meanings.sent3: The gardener accidentally restemmed the wrong plant, creating a funny mix-up.
meanings.sent4: Restemming the plant felt like giving it a fresh start in life.
meanings.sent5: She carefully restemmed the flower, hoping it would thrive in its new pot.

meanings.definition: To remove the stem or stems from (a plant) for propagation.
meanings.sent1: It is important to restem the succulent before replanting it.
meanings.sent2: Farmers restem certain crops to ensure better growth in the next season.
meanings.sent3: The botanist had to restem the plant without getting soil everywhere.
meanings.sent4: Restemming the plant was like giving it a fresh haircut for a new beginning.
meanings.sent5: She gently restemmed the herb, eager to see it flourish in a new environment.

meanings.definition: The act of cutting off the stem or stems of a plant for propagation.
meanings.sent1: The restem of the flower was necessary for its growth.
meanings.sent2: In gardening, the restem is a common practice for plant reproduction.
meanings.sent3: The restem of the plant was like a mini-surgery to ensure its future.
meanings.sent4: The restem of the plant symbolized a fresh start and new possibilities.
meanings.sent5: The careful restem of the seedling was crucial for its successful transplantation.
